head.title: Court Picks Trump In Fight for Resorts

hedline.hl1: Court Picks Trump In Fight for Resorts

LEAD: A Florida probate judge cleared the way yesterday for Donald J. Trump, the New York developer, to buy control of Resorts International Inc., the hotel and gambling casino operator, for $101 million in cash.

A Florida probate judge cleared the way yesterday for Donald J. Trump, the New York developer, to buy control of Resorts International Inc., the hotel and gambling casino operator, for $101 million in cash.

Judge Harold G. Featherstone of Dade County Probate Court approved the Trump deal over competing bids from Marvin Davis, the Denver oilman; Manos Sarantopoulos, a Greek businessman, and a group headed by Francis Purcell, a New York lawyer. The court took jurisdiction because the founder and controlling stockholder of Resorts International, James M. Crosby, was a resident of Florida at the time of his death in 1986.

Mr. Trump, who viewed Mr. Davis as his only serious competition, said the court's decision was a ''major upset for Marvin Davis,'' who, he added, was ''most intent on obtaining'' Resorts' casino at Paradise Island in the Bahamas.

The developer is thought to have been selected because of his ability to take on construction of the company's vast Taj Mahal casino-hotel in Atlantic City. Its cost has been estimated as high as $800 million.

In the decision that made the deal possible, Judge Featherstone approved a contract giving Mr. Trump the right to buy 390,783 shares of class B stock from the Crosby estate at $135 a share. That block alone represents 48 percent of the voting power of the company's class A and class B stock.

Mr. Trump would pay the same price for an additional 194,000 Class B shares owned by the Crosby family and is expected to announce a tender offer in about a month, after the estate deal is concluded, to buy about 170,000 class B shares owned by the public. There are no plans to buy the class A stock.
The Purcell group had offered $210 a share, and Mr. Sarantopoulos an estimated $170, while Mr. Davis had offered $140 plus an interest in the business.
